Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with tax laws and regulations.
Situation2: A seminar is being offered on potential tax law changes that may occur in the next few years.
Story: I stared at the invitation to the family’s annual Lunar New Year dinner, my mother’s handwriting looping across the envelope. She’d called earlier, reminding me how important it was to be there, how our traditions kept us close. I could almost hear her voice, gentle but firm, “You know how much it means to your grandmother.” At the same time, my inbox pinged with a reminder about the tax law seminar scheduled for the same evening. My manager had emphasized its importance, hinting that attending would show my commitment to staying ahead in our ever-changing field. I knew missing it could set me back, but missing the family dinner would disappoint everyone, especially my mother. My mind raced with the weight of both expectations—one rooted in love and heritage, the other in professionalism and ambition. I felt torn, the pressure building as I tried to imagine how I could possibly be in two places at once, wishing the choice didn’t have to be mine.
